awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: SWIFT: LARGE: MAC-on-MAC: A Spectrum Orchestrating Control Plane for Coexisting Wireless Systems
awd_abstract_narration:
Wireless systems with different radio access technologies (RATs) are becoming packed tightly in the space of radio spectrum. The carrier frequency and channel bandwidth of these systems, however, are drastically different across the spectrum domain, e.g., the IEEE 802.11 family that operates at 900 MHz, 2.4/5 GHz, and 60 GHz (mm-wave) bands, the 3GPP 5G family that spans 6-100 GHz, and more. Therefore, radio spectrum, which has long been identified as a scarce resource, will be more crowded and diversified than ever. Swift and effective spectrum sharing requires enhanced capability and increased intelligence at the wireless devices, from innovative transmitter and receiver technologies at the physical layer, to multi-band spectrum sensing across physical and MAC layer; from mapping spectrum slices for each access request, to radical modification of medium access control (MAC) protocols. Altogether, there is a need to support a myriad of heterogeneous devices that run diverse communication standards over different frequency bands to achieve efficient spectrum and energy utilization in such huge, dynamic and disparate systems.

This project mitigates the incoherent and disassociated frequency bands of the multi-RAT coexisting environments by exploiting the potential of cross-layer design from the circuits of transmitter and receiver, to the MAC layer with an innovative MAC-on-MAC spectrum control plane. This project has four major thrusts: (i) design of innovative transmitter and receiver techniques for energy-efficient multi-band spectrum monitoring, by using custom single-chip ultra-broadband (1-8 GHz) bio-inspired spectrum sensors to create a multi-band sensing solution that includes both sub-6 GHz and emerging mm-wave bands; (ii) methods to acquire complete spectrum occupancy information with a limited number of measurements from the proposed multi-band spectrum sensing circuits by exploiting matrix completion for low-cost, accurate and scalable monitoring through a learning-based sequential scheme; (iii) algorithms of obtaining a sorted ranking of paths that map a data flow to a range of spectrum slips by modeling spectrum-flow-RAT domains, finding the set of unoccupied spectrum slices, sorting out multiple recommendations from neighboring SAP control entities; (iv) creating MAC-Flow, a flow based network protocol that is capable of handling networking demands from both upper and lower layer, for both traditional user frames and for MAC-on-MAC controller processed frames for system-level performance evaluation. A holistic system-level integration of advances in spectrum detection, sensing, mapping with data flows, and implementation of MAC protocols is critical to improving spectrum utilization and user experience in coexisting wireless systems.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The goal of this SWIFT project  to discover new findings and to develop new algorithms for spectrum sharing in future wireless networks with fine-granularity 'spectrum slices." Specifically, our work aim to enhance spectrum efficiency and fair coexistence in next-generation wireless networks through four key contributions:

  1. Precise Spectrum Tenancy Discovery – Traditional spectrum sensing methods lack the granularity needed for LTE's Dynamic Spectrum Access (DSA). To address this, U-CIMAN is developed to decode LTE control signals, accurately uncovering spectrum occupancy, user locations, and traffic types at scheduling-level resolution. A Vector Autoregression model further characterizes spectrum usage by capturing temporal and inter-channel correlations.
  2. High-Accuracy LTE Resource Block (RB) Prediction – Existing prediction models suffer from low accuracy (dropping to 80%) when applied to fine-grained LTE RB usage. By extracting Modulation and Coding Scheme (MCS) data and employing a Deep Q-Network (DQN), prediction accuracy improves to 93%. A novel sample complexity upper bound reduces training data needs by 88.9%, making the solution practical for real-world deployment.
  3. Fine-Grained Spectrum Modeling for Nonexclusive Access – Current spectrum models fail to support next-gen shared spectrum access. FLuMe is introduced as a lightweight, data-driven model that tracks individual user spectrum usage in high resolution, revealing counterintuitive behaviors like reduced busy times under heavy traffic.
  4. Fair Multi-RAT Spectrum Sharing – To overcome fairness limitations in LAA/LBT, a mixed-integer programming framework optimizes access time allocation among coexisting Radio Access Technologies (RATs), validated via simulations for practical deployment.

Specifically, the research outcomes can be summarized as follows:

First, given that traditional spectrum sensing methods provide coarse-grained occupancy data, insufficient for LTE's Dynamic Spectrum Access (DSA). We developed a U-CIMAN framework to addresses these issues by decoding LTE control channels (e.g., PDCCH) to extract exact scheduling assignments, revealing spectrum occupancy at the same granularity as LTE’s resource allocation. Additionally, it infers user locations and traffic types from protocol fields. A Vector Autoregression (VAR) model is applied to capture temporal correlations and dependencies between adjacent channels. As a result, U-CIMAN achieves fine-grained, accurate spectrum occupancy mapping, enabling dynamic access to underutilized "spectrum holes." The VAR model successfully predicts channel availability patterns, improving DSA efficiency. Insights include identifying short idle periods (<10 ms) even under high traffic, challenging traditional spectrum models.

Second, we studied the spectrum prediction problem with a deep Q-network (DQN). Given that the 5G and 4G LTE share about 50-50 market as of 2025, while LTE networks provide much more mature and accessible usage, we tackle the spectrum prediction problem with a data-driven approach. Specifically,  existing models (e.g., MLP, on/off) perform poorly (80% accuracy) on LTE RB prediction due to fine time-frequency resolution. We introduces DQN with new features (e.g., MCS from DCI decoding) for improved learning. A sample complexity upper bound is derived, guiding an optimized experience replay method to reduce training data needs. The outcomes is that the enhanced DQN achieves 93% prediction accuracy, outperforming baseline models. The sample complexity reduction (88.9% less data) makes it feasible for real-time deployment. This enables better LTE-WiFi coexistence and adaptive video streaming.

Third, toward future and quick scheduling in spectrum sharing, we developed a spectrum mobility model, namely FLuMe, which is a data-driven model that tracks individual user spectrum usage via four key variables, derived from high-resolution LTE control decoding. The proposed Frame-Level spectrum Model (FLuMe) includes the camping time, the inter-access time, the hopping distance, and the tenancy width, by monitoring spectrum ten- ancy in the same time-frequency resolutions as scheduling. The model parameters are studied under low, medium, and high wireless traffic conditions, and it captures short-term dynamics missed by classical models, in comparing to current spectrum models that lack granularity for nonexclusive access. We further stud the distributions and the correlations among the model parameters, based on large amounts of spectrum data achieved through the real world measurement and the post-processing. Interestingly, FLuMe reveals counterintuitive trends, such as decreased busy times under high traffic, challenging traditional assumptions. Validations confirm it accurately models millisecond-level spectrum variations, critical for shared access algorithms.

Finally, we investigate a practical issue in spectrum sharing among multiple Radio Access Technology (multi-RAT). Our main approach is to formulate access time allocation as a mixed-integer programming problem, solved via a two-step optimization for efficiency because of our observations in measuring multi-RAT coexistence. Our algorithms is evaluated by extensive simulations, which show near-optimal fairness across RATs while maintaining low computational overhead. The framework adapts to varying allocation intervals, enabling scalable coexistence in 5G/6G networks.

Together  these advances enable efficient, dynamic, and fair spectrum utilization in future wireless networks. The research outcomes not only provide data-driven observations and insights that had not been revealed in prior studies, but also laid a solid foundation with accurate modeling and practical algorithms for implementation in real systems.
